name: placeholder
content:
placeholder noun [C]
(TEXT/IMAGE/OBJECT)
Add to word list
Add to word list
a piece of text or an image that is put in a document temporarily before the final text or image is added later: Currently we are using a stock image we found as a placeholder. You can replace the placeholder text manually.
an object that is put somewhere temporarily before the final thing is added later: Surgeons had cleaned the eye socket and fitted it with a foam placeholder ready for a prosthetic eye.
mathematics, computing
  specialized a symbol or piece of text in a mathematical expression or computer instruction that can be replaced by particular pieces of information: A placeholder variable p represents the result of a computation in progress. If you use a ? as a placeholder, it adds spaces for insignificant zeros on either side of the decimal point, so decimal points align.

placeholder noun [C]
(JOB/POSITION)
someone who does another more important person's job temporarily: Ted may or may not be a placeholder for Beau. After being named interim president of California's stem cell institute, Murphy said he had no intention of serving merely as a placeholder until a permanent president is found.
UK someone who has an official or government position, especially because they supported the people in power, rather than because they deserved to get the position: At the start of his time in office, analysts were asking if he was a placeholder or a real Prime Minister.

placeholder noun [C]
(AMERICAN FOOTBALL)
sports
  specialized in American football, a player who holds the ball in a vertical position on the ground so another player can kick it: The placeholder's job is to call for the ball, catch it, and place it just right for the kicker.
